Arôme enveloppante de vanille, accompagnée de notes de malt rôti, de café et de chocolat. En bouche, laccent est davantage sur le malt, mais lassemblage demeure des plus convainquants. Bonne rondeur. Rafraîchissante si consommée froide.

Pour from a bottle into a small plastic water glass, because thats all that was offered at this conference. Served at ~60 degrees because I cant find an ice machine, but eff it. Dark pour with a billowing cola head that collapses to a dense cap and nice lacing. Aroma is slightly subdued with notes of cherry, lightly astringent roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate. I get some almost sour notes initially which really work well here and heighten the perception of fruit. Taste is lots of bitter cocoa and coffee up front, moving to sweeter notes of vanilla, lightly roasted caramel malt, more chocolate. Indistinct fruit notes throughout Finishes slightly bitter with a lasting cocoa and vanilla aftertaste. Silky smooth mouthfeel. I really liked this one, delivers a good deal of complexity at an ABV much lower than I would have thought, making it easy to enjoy a full bottle of. The only not enjoyable thing about this beer was its price, which at 7.45 a 500 ml bottle is going to prevent me from searching this out again.

Bottle shared by craftbeerdesign. Pours black with just a bit of light at the edges. Taste is coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, molasses with vanilla that is delicately integrated. The vanilla is just ever so light and not overly sweet. Nice indeed.

Norfolk bottle. Glad I found this on the back end cap. Typical stout pour, completely opaque with a tan head. Nice lacing. Huge aroma of coffee mixed with sugar and milk. Outstanding flavor and silky smooth mouthfeel. Flavor reminds me of sweetened espresso at first but then some lingering bitterness. Very subtle vanilla.

Une robe ténébreuse et sa mousse abondante et pleine de ténacité. Un nez de bon café fort, de grains maltés rôtis et de notes chocolatées qui transpirent une vanille naturelle et de grande qualité. Des parfums brillamment agencés. Un goût bien travaillé par la noirceur des grains rôtis et torréfiés. Mes papilles aiment bien cette sensation chocolatée crémeuse, ces saveurs fraîches de café et cette élégante touche vanillée. En bouche, mon palais est ravi par cette texture gonflée par lavoine. Le pétillement doux prolonge les saveurs. En finale, une charmante apparition des houblons : une signature adorable des cultivars à travers cette aimable obscurité. Une autre fantastique bière de cette maison toujours très intéressante.

Picked up a bottle of this in Boston. Pours dark brown, with a thin head. Nose and taste are roast, malt, chcolate, vanilla. I thought the vanilla was a bit on the heavy side. Some coffee. Nice mouthfeel. Pretty good.

On tap @ Blind Tiger House. Deep dark brown in the glass, almost black actually and it has a small sidesticking and islandy top. Really nice dark chocolate nose. Some sweetness found and nuts, coffee and roasted malts are definitely present also. As is a bit of leather. Smells really nice. It has that cloudy light mouthfeel - almost like drinking a cloud. Vanilla extract and a hint of sour wood. Damn, that was really suiting in this beer. It kinda cuts off the roastiness and the chocolate paper. Loaded with vanilla goods also this. Delicious to drink. Leaving a slightly dry and chocolate like flavor in the mouth. Really good! 12.06.2013
Subtle tastes of vanilla not tasting any coffee notes. A very solid one none the less..
Had this on tap with nitro it was pretty good. Nice and smooth with a malty caramel flavor

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 Sampled on draft at the House of 1000 beers this beer poured a black color with a small foamy beige head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was dry, smoky, woody, roasty and had a bit of vanilla. The flavor was roasty and malty with notes of vanilla, cream, a bit of smoke, crisp fruity hops, a bit of toast and whiskey. Long roasty vanilla, toasty and smoke finish. Moderately full bodied. Smoother than I expected and I found that the subtle smokiness really worked for me. Interesting.

Awesome 12 oz glass at lord hobo, great strong vanilla aroma and flavor with nice viscous stout base. Awesome

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Roasted malt, licorice and vanilla flavors. Bitter sweet finish. Very good stout.
Very carbonated.  Sweet and bitter malt.  Lors of vanilla.  Pretty thin but expected at 6.5%.  Would be a lot better if thicker and stronger.
Bottle from Halftime Beverage. Dark brown, ruby hues, roasted malt aroma, light vanilla sweetness. Lots of malt taste.

Bottle shared by Dogbrick on Memorial Day. Darkest brown in color with a thick tan head. Malty and roasty nose with vanilla and chocolate notes. Flavor starts roasty, but quickly turns to vanilla and chocolate sweetness before a bitter coffee finish.

16.9oz bottle, bottled 02/19/13, thanks to Mike L. Shared with DanielCoor. Dark brown color. Good thin light brown head. Lots of splotchy lace. Medium-plus body. Moderate chewiness. Smooth, creamy lighter carbonation. Some roasty malt, light dark chocolate, moderate vanilla, not too strong, its in check. Hint of coffee. Good moderate sweet taste, lighter bitter. A little sweet, but a solid stout

Sample at the Memorial Day Deck Beers tasting on 05/27/2013: Pours an opaque brown-black color with a medium tan head that recedes gradually. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Light to medium body with a roasty character and flavors of coffee and dark chocolate. The finish is mildly bitter with a burnt malt and coffee aftertaste. Above average overall.

Bottle.  Pours black with thin tan film of a head.  Some drippy spaced out lacing.  Nose of burnt toast and chocolate malt.  Vanilla bean start to finish. Body is on the lighter side of medium and lingers, as finish is same as body.   A highly drinkable stout which is solidly presented.  Yum.

From bottle. Nice rich malty aroma, smoke, charred coffee, light vanilla. A bit of tang and earth, lactose. Dark black opaque with thin cocoa-brown lacing head. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Starts dry with lots of roasted character, mild coffee and char. Some light carbonic acidity with medium bitterness. Finish is light sweet with medium bitterness. Can just taste the vanilla here but its subtle. Charred bittersweet after.
Bottle, as pictured.  Poured a nice dark brown/black with tan head.  Smells and tastes strongly of vanilla and lightly of coffee.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  Good beer.

Bottle via trade with Thedrooid...Dans the man!  Dark mahogany pour with an ebony core and mocha colored head.  Rich gooey brownie batter, fudge, and vanilla bean.  Ghirardelli, Godiva, and Hersheys are jealous!  Another well crafted brew from Maine!

Bouteille 500ml. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de malt rôti, moyen de café, léger de chocolat noir, de vanille et de houblon herbeux avec quelques traces de cendre. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi quune texture moyennement crémeuse. Léger goût de vanille avec de faibles traces lactiques de crème brûlée lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti avec des notes de pain grillé et de chocolat noir puis en finale lon retrouve une légère amertume de houblon herbeux aux petites notes résineuses avec un léger-moyen goût de café. Post-goût moyen-long, léger-moyen amer de rôti, moyen-léger de houblon herbeux aux notes résineuses avec un moyen goût de café ainsi que des traces de vanille et de chocolat.

You have to love a local for local trade that brings you something completely unexpected.  Thanks to RABinVA for hooking me up.  Pours like black coffee with a tan head.  While I expected the smell to be of vanilla, I detected more nutmeg.  I also expected the vanilla to make it very sweet, but it had just a touch which blended well into this beer.  Bottle - Trade from RABinVA

Love it! Another beautifully balanced beer that I will crush whenever I can find it. Aged on vanilla beans so it gives you that POP! Coffee notes hushed down by the sweetness, making it a very approachable sweet stout. If you get the chance, drink this on nitro (like Guinness), it will be an unforgettable experience.

5 ounce sample at the Freeport tasting room.  Roasted coffee and chocolate, malted milk.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle from a trade, thanks cp45!

Pours pitch black with a smooth brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, hints of chocolate, vanilla and coffee.Taste is smooth, sweetish and roasty with hints of vanilla, chocolate and coffee. Finish is sweetish with loads of vanilla and chocolate. Quite nice, sweetish and balanced stout.

Some of the junk hanging in the shower stalls at Rikers Island are not as black as this beer. Very deep black pour with a tan head. Aromas of roast and some nutty flavor. Taste is kind of meh... Not as good as I was expecting. Too much twang and not enough cigarette butts and asphalt. Ehh...  Scroll past.
From a bottle. Pours dark opaque brown with a thin tan head. Smells like roasted coffee and raisins. Tastes like bitter coffee and licorice. Light body and medium carbonation.

Bottle. Pours opaque black with thick, tan head; decent retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, earthy and spicy hops, and fig. Flavor is roast malts forward with supporting vanilla, dark fruit esters, light toffee, and earthy hops; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle (500 ml). Black with a huge creamy and slowly diminishing creamy beige head and some lacing. Aroma is of vanilla (not overwhelming), roasted malt, coffee and bitter chocolate... quite complex for a 6.5% abv Stout. Taste is sligthly to moderately sweet with vanilla, roasted malt, coffe, bitter chocolate and slight bitter finish. Medium body. As the description says, the mouthfeel is silky. Good Stout. Not awesome, but well constructed. Good balance between vanilla and roasted malt.

Bottle.  Pitch black with a thin but firm tan head, a bit cratered.  The aroma is flat-out dessert-like, rich like a chocolate milkshake.  This drinks like a liquid brownie, too ... the vanilla but a subtle layer within the baked yumminess.  (#5004, 5/4/2013)

Wow, this beer was boring. Supplied by Jblauvs: thanks, man. Tasted algae and faint roast, maybe some milk chocolate by swallow alongside soy beans, burnt toast and vanilla extract. It could just been a bad year, but this was not memorable whatsoever.

375 ml bottle from trade with seth_lfod.  Thanks Seth!  Pours pitch black with a perfect 1 finger head that fades slowly and leaves great webbing on the glass.  Aroma is faint but nice, mostly vanilla and medium roasted coffee with hints of chocolate, anise, cream, and burnt toast.  Taste is awesome.  Lots of roasted coffee, vanilla, and burnt toast.  Some light smoke, chocolate and cream.  Light sweetness and a fairly strong bitterness.  Very smooth, long finish of coffee, vanilla, and cream.  Everything seems to balance out here, my kinda stout.  Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation.  My first Maine Beer Co. beer and I will definitely be seeking out more now.  I think this is my favorite non-imperial stout Ive ever had.  Love it.
Good stout, not great.  Pretty hoppy, chocolate, carbonation, dry finish.  Probably a little over carbonated for the style, but good beer overall.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Pours brown with a nice beige head, aroma of chocolate, cherries, butter cookies, vanilla, flavor of dark bread, smoke, vanilla, cherry sourness and some chocolate, medium bodied

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Black with a light brown head. Roasty aroma with dark chocolate and some vanilla. Roasty flavor, pretty sweet, with vanilla, chocolate a finish with some bitterness. Medium-bodied. Decent.

Pours a pitch black with a small, brownish head. Looks menacing enough to drink.Cocoa, cream, vanilla bean and coffee aromas unfold as it warms up to room temperature. Very inviting.Wow. Vanilla bean, cream and roasted coffee mingle together, finishing in an orgasm of all three flavors. Very palatable. Vanilla lingers the longest on my palate, followed by cream. A light, but memorable finish to an excellent beer.Its an interesting thing to do with a regular stout and in this case, the aging compliments this stout. Check it out!!!

Loved this beer! Great taste with a hint of vanilla. Not a huge stout but one of the better ones I have tasted. Also great price.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Half Time Beverage. Good aroma, sweet. Chocolate, vanilla, marshmallow. Dark Blackish Brown color, good head and lace. Sweet flavor.  Lighter body, smooth  creamy mouthfeel. Sweet dry finish. Pretty darn tasty. Nice mix with vanilla and chocolate, oat adds nice creamy texture.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Cant remember who brought this but thanks! Been wanting to try this for awhile now. Good vanilla and chocolate mixture here. Very easy to drink and might even age well too.

Pitch black coloured body with a thinnish, one centimetre light brown head - nice. Oily on top with absolutely no light showing through at all - 100% opaque. Nice aroma of cherries, milk, coffee, anise and tons of roasted malt, vanilla and oak. Medium-bodied; Assertive roasted malt flavour with a hint of peat and a lot of sweetness on end. Aftertaste shows mostly vanilla, oak, cherries, peat and a good coffee and earthy finish. Overall, a nice rich and deep stout that makes it feel that itll be an imperial stout, but the lower alcohol makes for a nice beer and relatively easy to drink! Definitely worth trying if you can find this one and if you like any style of beer at all! I sampled this 50 cL bottle purchased from Liqour Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 24-February-2013 for US$6.11 sampled at home in Washington on 15-April-2013. 

Brewed on 27-January-2013, Bought 24-February-2013, Sampled 15-April-2013

poured from a bottle into a snifter. Very dark pour, oil black with a creamy thick head that is light brown in appearance. Aroma is cereal, chocolate, some vanilla. Taste is very smooth. Dark chocolate, a bit of coffee from the dark malts. Really getting a nice roasted flavor from this. The vanilla isnt very pronounced, but there is a nice organic base of it as an undertone. Nice and flavorful. More ceral notes than normally expected of out of stouts I drink.

This is nice! Pours jet black with a light tan foamy head and lots of lacing. Nose is roasted malt and a hint of espresso. Aromas of slight dark fruit, some espresso, some burnt toast, some light chocolate and vanilla. Taste is medium sweet with medium bitterness. Very silky in the mouth with light carbonation. Great beer!
On tap at Pizza Paradiso Dupont Circle. Dark black body with slight head. Nose is faint, of chocolate. Taste is lots of chocolate and vanilla. Bitter in the finish.
Near black with beige lacing. Sweetish, coffee, licorice, vanilla, moderate hops. Very well balanced, a bit thin on mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Very nice overall.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2013 500 ml, bottled 11-11-12. Thanks Phatdog1! Ebony with a lasting film of cream. Nose is vanilla and caramel, with touches of sour chocolate, toasted grain and coffee. Flavor is all the same in a well blended mix, with some lactose tartness and a hint of ash.  Medium body is smooth with light medium carbonation and well balanced. Excellent stout, with just the right touch of vanilla.
Merv says this is better than Black.  500 ml bottle at Pizza Paradiso.  Pours deep black small tan head.  Awesome.

These guys really know how to make simple, clean, delicious beer.  This one poured a medium to dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma was light coffee, dark chocolate, and vanilla cake.  Flavor was similar only more intense. vanilla is definitely there, but not overwhelming at all, greatly balanced by the roasted bitterness of the coffee flavors. great stuff!

Bottle from trade with Phatdog1. Black, average, disappearing head, too subtle and nondescript aroma for me. Taste hits initially with a big chocolate taste and vanilla notes, and its nice. However, there is a thin quality in the middle that makes we want something more out of this. Finishes pretty well, with some bitterness coming out in the end. Decent but a little thin.
Bottle.  Pours black with some tan head and spotted lacing.  Aromas of coffee, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate. Lot more vanilla comes through on the palate with dark chocolate and lactose.
Deep and dark with a thin tan head. Roasty, toasty malt with a very smooth mouth feel. No grittiness at all. Cocoa, vanilla, malt. Long and smooth finish. Quite a good stout.

Pours almost black & thick looking with a khaki head of tight  foam that shrank slowly to a couple of big islands on top.  Soapy lace.  Nose is cocoa, sweet vanilla beans, roasted coffee, grass & earth.  A hint of char, medicinal alcohol that kept coming forward as it warmed and way in back some faint  floral.  Taste is smooth, on the heavy side but velvety.  Vanilla, burnt coffee, burnt toast, roasted grains, bitter chocolate.  I didnt taste a lot of char but some and I am tasting some oats and some alcohol.   Finishes semi wet and a little ashy.  The hops were in there I can tell by the underlying fruit sweetness and a bit of slick oil that lightly coats the tongue.  Bitterness is very light considering all that roasted toasted and burnt. This is a hearty and favorable stout that is not too complex and has a lot to enjoy.
Bottle->snifter.  Deep brown with tan head.  Aroma: deep malt, coffee, vanilla.  Taste: chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt.  Bitter aftertaste.  Nice.
Nice and full taste with a small hint of vanilla. Maybe a bit of some smoky flavours too. Nice beer!

500ml bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black with tan head. Aroma is of dark chocolate, coffee, and slight vanilla. Taste is dark roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, ash, with a hint of vanilla. Excellent stout

Poured from a pint bottle shared at Ryans.  Pours a cloudy dark brown, almost black, with a tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and chocolate.  Flavors of roasted malt with a hint of vanilla.  Bitter burnt finish.
500ml bottle shared by jsprime. black with a tan head. aroma of vanilla and coffee. the flavour is all blackmalts + vanilla. well balanced between all the elements, very good stout.
Robust chocolate malt aroma. Dark black color with a medium dark tan head. Moderate bitter beginning with a light sweet finish. Palate has a chalky beginning and creamy end.

Pours a deep brown with a light brown head which lingers quite well.  Aroma of vanilla flavored coffee grounds, taste is a rather smooth albeit thin coffee, and pulpy wood taste.  The mouthfeel is a bit too thin for what is expected, but if that is increased this would be a great brew as it has a taste which is unique.
Charred oak aroma. Black, medium tan head, nice lacing. Astringent, dry, medium body, easy carbonation, almost creamy. Flavor is nondescript, charcoal and no discernible nuance.
500 ml - Fleeting head, some lace. No nose despite the dark roast. Hoped for more, no depth. A rare miss for this brewer.

500 ml bottle courtesy of jtclockwork. Thanks. Pours a dense black color with a small khaki head that has fair retention. The aroma is big and bold with mocha, coffee and vanilla. The taste, like the nose, features mocha, coffee and vanilla, but also adds a new dimension of well roasted grains, burnt toast and bitter walnuts. The palate is full, creamy and silky smooth with soft carbonation. Finishes long and dry. Overall: First rate stout. I was afraid that this was going to overly sweet as is often the case with vanilla bean stouts, but it did not turn out that way at all. Very nice tasty stuff.

01/27/2013 vintage, 500 ml bottle into a tulip glass. 

A - Pours a jet black body with tons of mocha foam. Dies down quickly but leaves behind excellent lacing and retention. 

S - Really huge blast of coffee beans, milk chocolate and sweet vanilla. A bit minerally on the finish. There is something about this aroma that reminds me a lot of HIll Farmsteads Everett, but it falls a bit short.

T - Coffee, chocolate malts, sweet vanilla and some light roast. Quite tasty. 

M - Medium bodied and creamy.

O - Perhaps it was my inclination to stack this up against double and imperial stouts....but that is not what this beer is. Its a relatively moderate ABV stout with a solid coffee and vanilla flavor. Its tasty and enjoyable, but not exactly world class. Once again I feel conflicted on the price tag of an MBC beer....

Bottle from Nathaniels.  Pours a dark black color with a nice, thick, tan head. Strong notes of coffee, vanilla, and chocolate. Flavor consists of vanilla with a nice hit of coffee. Amazing balance and a nice bite in the finish. Very enjoyable stout.
Bottle from canals. Nice aromas of roast, coffee and vanilla. The body was a tad watery / thin for my tastes, but it held its own.
Bottle from spence. Pours jet black with ruby edges silky tan head with great retention. Nose of chocolate, mild roast, and vanilla. Taste follows with nice balance. Silkey smooth body. Outstanding!

bottle from recent trade with phatdog01; thanks Craig.  aroma was mostly roasted malt to me; maybe slight vanilla.   black pour.  palate is med; nice level of carbonation that helps with the flavor - flavor is much much roast.  good not great stout.

Dec. 2011 bottle. Pours a clear dark brown. Classic aroma for a RIS: big malt, coffee, licorice, sweet vanilla syrup, and a bit of rhubarb.  Taste of smooth oak, a hint of vanilla, and a big coffee finish. Velvet body.  Not bad.

Bottle shared by portableparty.  Clear dark brown pour, minimal carbonation and a nutty cocoa aroma.  Flavor was also roasty dry cocoa, just enough malt to give it enough body and finished a little dry.  Really nice!
Bottle. Pours dark with little head.  Aroma is coffee,  roasted malts and other nice notes.  Flavor is solid,  nothing crazy but a good stout.
Bottle. Pours dark brown black. Good head. Tastes smells if coffee chocolate dark roast. Small vanilla. It was good but half way thru just too much roasted taste for me.

500 ml. bottle to glass. Pours light black brown with a tight khaki head that leaves a wispy film and foamy collar lacing. Aroma has strong coffee roasted malt and faint vanilla. Taste is coffee roasted malt vanilla and roasted malt flavors. Palate is thin slick and drying. Solid.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle at Jeffs tasting. Reddish brown pour. Not overly heavy. Vanilla and coffee in this. Pretty straightforward but very well made.

16oz bottled January 27, 2013.  Served at cellar temperature.

Pours black with a three finger creamy/foamy brown head that slowly recedes to a small foamy cap and leaves nice rings and webs of lacing behind.

Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, sweet-smelling and dessert-like.  Good to very good strength.

Flavor is rich vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, some caramel, moderate sweetness, some bitterness, minimal alcohol.  Tasty.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, pretty smooth and creamy but a bit of a carbonation bite too.

Really tasty vanilla Stout.  The vanilla isnt subtle, its definitely here and a big component of this brew, nice chocolate notes too.  Ive got one more bottle that Ill sit on for a couple of months to let the hops fade out a bit which I think would help.

Drunk from a Sam Smith english-style pint glass. Pours the color of strong French press coffee with a beautiful thick fluffy head that reminds me of dirty roadside snow.  Strong aromas of vanilla extract. Weighty and slightly viscus on the palate... 

The best way I can aptly describe the overall experience of this beer is to admit that it evokes some deep-ceded childhood memories. As a kid we all had one friend whos mother always ended up chauffeuring you to soccer games. You spent long drives in the unvacuumed third row seats of a minivan while she chain smoked and drank way too much Dunkin Donuts French Vanilla. And then your team lost.

Bottle at home. Pour is deep brown, almost black with a creamy khaki head and great lacing. Roast, light peat, molasses, maple syrup, vanilla, coffee, somewhat oaky aroma. Taste is big dark chocolate, espresso, sweet vanilla, bread, wood, earthy, and nutty with a big roasted coffee aftertaste. Creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Coffee, chocolate cake with vanilla frosting. Nice!

Poured from a pint-sized bottle into a pint glass to drink.  The beer had a full, rich black color with a wet consistency and a large creamy lighter tan head with good retention, and great lacing and cling.  Its aroma featured powerful notes of roasty vanilla with compliments of chocolate and coffee, along with some earthy and cereal hops.  The taste was initially a pleasant sweet vanilla with lighter malty tones of chocolate and caramel, and a modest earthy and cereal bitterness as it settled.  Its body was crisp, creamy, and wet with a semi-watery, but filling mouthfeel with lower carbonation and a slightly dry finish.  Great beer, thanks Siobhan!

Okay so I support local brewers 110%. This beer did not meet expectations as labeled. I did not detect vanilla. Neither did the person with whom unshared this beer. And is was pricey. 16 ounces of beer for 7.99. A bit watery. Body and no butt. No head retention. It is chocolately. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nose has amazing notes of vanilla and chocolate, but the taste is actually a bit overbearing on the vanilla and has a slightly over-roasted quality to it.  A very good beer, mind, but strangely a bit too much of a good thing in some ways.

Black with a large, rocky, tan head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, light sour milk, coffee bean. Full bodied, creamy. Flavor is cocoa, roasted malts, vanilla, sweet cream, a bit of dark fruit. Very enjoyable. Not something I could do more than one or two of in a night, but would do it multiple times a week.
Draft. Black pour, tan head, little retention/lace. Aroma of coffee, cream, dark chocolate, roast. Taste is sweet, creamy, dark chocolate, roast. Palate is fizzy, creamy, rich finish.

Pours cola brown with a tan foam head.  Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, and coffee.  Sweet flavor with chocolate upfront followed quickly vanilla with an undercurrent of roasted malt with hint of coffee.  Very enjoyable.
Awesome dark stout robust coffee and intense high gravity expensive as Time Out but smooth all the way

Nice, full tan head with good retention and sticky lace. Fairly black hued with a murky brown edging. Soft nose of chocolate, vanilla, roast and some coffee notes. Medium bodied with a gentle carbonation, lil oily, chewy and a touch priclkly. Easy and tasty flavors of chocolate, roast and vanilla, some light cherry notes and a hint of black patent.Nice, dry roasty finish is a little chalky Bottle from statelineliquors. .

Bottle from Gianni - thanks!  Black pour with a dark tan head.  Aroma is light vanilla, chocolate, roast, slight coffee, abd maybe some minimal hop biterness.  Taste is vanilla bean with dry chocolate and coffee followed by darker chocolate notes.  Dry and clean mouthfeel.  Good beer but almost too clean and tight in its engineering with the stout aspects seeming slightly sterile.
Bottle in NYC sept 2012. Black beer with a beige head. Coffee and vanilla aroma. Bitter coffee and some vanilla flavour. Nice beer :-)

Bouteille de 500 ml. Arômes assez délicats de vanille et de torréfaction. Robe noire et opaque, peu de mousse et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, la bière développe de belles notes chocolatées appuyées par quelques accents de vanille. Le corps demeure assez svelte, ce qui rend la bière plutôt facile à boire. Finale assez douce et chocolatée, présentant peut-être une légère touche métallique. Une stout relativement simple, mais agréable.

Pours dark brown with a lasting, creamy light brown head.  Smells of vanilla, chocolate, roasty malt. Tastes of vanilla, some roasted malt, some tartness on the finish. Id like this better without the vanilla.

Bottle from Spirits Berkeley. Pours a very nice looking pitch black with a small tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, roast, mild vanilla, light coffee and some mild bitterness. Taste is complex, with a nice silky mouthfeel. Chocolate, light coffee, vanilla, light coffee, with some more lingering vanilla bean in the finish. Well done.

Very dark brown, small pretty dark brown head.  Aroma chocolate, toasty malt, caramel.  Medium body.  Flavor on the sweet side but with good balance.  Cocoa, pleasantly grainy, creamy finish.  Vanilla minimal.  Very drinkable.  Nice.

Deep brown/black pour.  Aroma is clean roast malt, cocoa, mild caramel, and artificial vanilla.  Flavor is a soft, semi-gritty roast with very faint vanilla sweetness.  Clean roast finish.  A bit dull with nothing really showcased.  Average palate presence.
Very tasty stout.  Other people have tried this but this is the best stout with vanilla I can remember having.  Soft carbonation. Bottle from Capones.
50cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2010, with vanilla, thx to kraddel!, complex Stout, malty/roasted and slightly spicy/sweet, balanced, cloudy, good head, good brew

Poured out into a shaker. Black with a one finger head. Smells of chocolate, hops, and a little vanilla. Taste is way more vanilla follows by chocolate and a little hop bitterness... subtle coffee in there as well.

bottle at home
pours black, foam is very light brown to white. fading, but stays . 
aroma is not intense at all. i can pick up some vanilla, yet i have to search for it . 
taste is .. 
realy drinkable ( not to much carbo , light mouthfeel, thinner thing) 
you have the softness ( vanilla prob) some sweetness ( cacao? ) some roasted malts. nothing realy highlights here. just a very drinkable good stout to drink in bars in stead of lagers or such. yet not the next big thing in the land of beers .

Trade from Phatdog1 - Thanks! Pours black, with a beige head that my notes call "adorable" (I had been drinking...). Smells like Dark Chocolate and marshmallow, plus a significant amount of coffee. Taste is Chocolate and marshmallow again, almost decadent. Very rich and flavorful.

Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a large, frothy and creamy tan head, long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is vanilla, roast and dark chocolate malt, coffee notes, earthy hops and prune esters.  Flavor is malt dominant with vanilla notes, leather, oak, light hops and bitterness, dark fruity esters, with a dry finish.  Medium to full body with medium carbonation.

Poured into a plastic cup from the Holiday Inn - is about the same color as a cola and has a medium brown head. Nose is coffee bean and roasted malt. Taste is black coffee with a hint of chocolate. Mouthfeel is thin and the finish is lingering.

50cl bottle.  Medium tan head atop cola black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, cocoa, roast, light vanilla.  Taste is medium sweet, bittersweet chocolate, roast, light vanilla, faint ash.  Light-medium body, low carbonation.

The beer looks great on the pour. Just what I would expect a stout to look like... dark, opaque, nice creamy head. Not so sure about the aroma. Seems a little flat. All Im really picking up is a lot of barnyard and cereal...maybe some subtle notes under there.

I can taste the vanilla and a hint of cocoa...but the sweetness seems a tad artificial. The mouthfeel is pretty dry in spite of the mild sweetness...a little thin. Again, the cereal and barnyard take over. Finish is mildly hoppy....ashy.

Not bad but nothing I would seek out.
Draft. Black pour with cloudy head.  Flavor is malts, some spices and off tones. Not a big fan. Aroma is light for a stout.
Black pour, soft head, excellent lacing.  This was a gift from mcox90.  Thank you!  Nice vanilla aroma.  Chocolate vanilla taste,  End leaves a lingering bitter feeling in mouth.

Bottle. Pours a dark black color with a nice, thick, tan head. Strong notes of coffee, vanilla, and chocolate. Flavor consists of vanilla with a nice hit of coffee. Amazing balance and a nice bite in the finish. Very good stout.

It poured a dark black-brown with a half centimeter of white head. The fifteen second head dissipates and leaves a film on top of the body. The smell was a mixture between coffee, cocoa and vanilla. The taste had the vanilla and cocoa mixed well and in front with the coffee coming in just to blend in. The palate was about a medium with a moderate carbonation leaving a nice acceptable dryness. Id say it was fairly drinkable. Overall, another well done beer by one of Maines best beer companies.

Bottle shared by mdfb79. Thanks Dan.

The beer is dark brown with a beige head that leaves ample lacing stuck to the glass. The aroma offers some pleasant roast and chocolate notes. Lots of tasty roast in the flavor as well. Light bodied and really easy to drink. I would have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-13-2012

Bottle of batch 1 thanks to FooFaa, pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, and hops. Taste of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate. Not amazing but nice and drinkable, a lighter stout.
500ml bottle-rich foamy lt brown head with trailing lace-black.  A-rich dk malt-roasty/cocoa, some earthy.  T-dk malt-roasty/ashy/cocoa/anise, earthy hops.  Occasional.

12oz bottle form Deciccos Ardsley. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, and bit of espresso. Flavor of roasted malts, vanilla, and some chocolate and very light coffee. Body is a little thin, but this is a pretty solid stout.

Bottle @ Chriso. Pours a black color with a small longlasting tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma. Roasted malty sweetish chocolate vanilla and coffee flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate and coffee finish.

Had to rate something on 12/12/12 -- 16.9oz bottle from Liquor Shop in Tyngsboro,MA.  Muddy dark brown with moderate creamy tan head.  Aroma is primarily cocoa with a touch of coffee and vanilla.  Flavor is relatively straightforward up front with sharp coffee notes but fades into a complex finish of chocolate, vanilla, and through a myriad of rich roast malts.  Complexity really shows up as the beer warms...when cold, the finish is a bit sharp.  Nice stout.

pours dark (almost black) with moderately thick brown head.  the aroma is mostly roast, coffee, and cocoa; these are also predominant in the taste, although some very nice vanilla flavor starts to come through at the end. overall, the vanilla is understated and the beer is fairly dry.  medium body.  very drinkable - a nice change of pace from some of the more extreme imperial stouts.

500 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Very dark brown, almost black, pour with a creamy brown head.  Faint aroma of vanilla that is mostly overpowered by dark cocoa, charred malts, and roasted coffee.  Nice dark roasted malt flavor with notable coffee and dark chocolate and a more subdued vanilla in the background.  Medium bodied and full of flavor yet quite drinkable at only 6.5% ABV.  Nice beer!

Bottle. Black pour with a short, dark brown head. Aroma is cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee notes, roasted malt and light vanilla notes. Taste is bigger vanilla, coffee, roasted malt, burnt caramel, cocoa and dark chocolate. Body is medium with a strong, bubbly, but creamy, carbonation. Ends slightly more bitter with cocoa, vanilla, stronger coffee, roasted malt and burnt caramel.

Bottle. Poured almost black with a thick caramel-colored head. Aroma of chocolate and some coffee. Both were also present in the flavor along with some roasted malt notes and then finishing with a non-overpowering vanilla flavor.

Bottle. Pours dark brown/black, with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, dark fruit, and vanilla. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, vanilla, fruit, and chocolate. Medium to light body. I think an imperial version of this would be intriguing.

Dark brown almost black with a coffee colored head.  Sweet roasted malt aroma with coffee, chocolate,  vanilla and bourbon notes.  Rich roasted malt flavor with brownsugar, chocolate and vanilla flavors. This is a rich flavorful brew.

Pours very dark with chocolate highlights and a coffee colored head.  The aroma is sweet with ground espresso, chocolate, vanilla, and roasted meat coming through strongly.  On the palate, it is sweet and round with cafe-au-lait balanced out with tannic roasty notes.  Not terribly exciting, but really well executed and tasty.

Bottle at Chriso tasting, thanks Chris, 18/11/12.
Very dark mahogony brown approaching black with a thin tan head that departs to the edges.
Nose is roast malt, light molasses, hops, a touch of ginger.
Taste comprises roast malt, chocolate, molasses, hops, a little background pine.
Medium bodied with soft carbonation leading to a roasted dry finish.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Half liter bottle from WIne Warehouse. Pours a hazy very dark brown color with a thin brown head. Decent head retention. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, dry vanilla, peppery hops. The taste is cocoa, citrus, vanilla, lemongrass, mild roasty notes. Medium bodied. Unexpected and quite interesting. Nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, almost black, with a medium brown head.  Aroma is roasty, chocolate, with just a little vanilla, somewhat metallic  Taste is medium sweet with a good light roasted bitterness, a good amount of cocoa, but just a little vanilla.  Finish is dry, roasty, and a little metallic.  Medium body, soft carbonation.  Really solid stout, but not worth the $6.99 price tag for a 500ml bottle.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle at Fire Works Leesburg.  It pours a muddy looking brown with a small head.  The nose has notes of cocoa powder and mocha.  The flavor is a nice mix of cocoa, slight roasted malt, coffee, and a light vanilla sweetness.  The finish is surprisingly dry.  Almost a sweet stout up front and a dry one on the back.  Wonderfully drinkable.  Great example of the style.

Bottle into a goblet. Pours a dark brown without much head, which leaves a bit to be desired. The cocoa and vanilla are in great balance, noticeable but not overbearing. Smooth, slightly creamy mouthfeel with a bit of a dry finish. Great stout from a brewery that so far has impressed with their pale ales.

A nice near black with a chocolate milk foam head. Nice aroma of roast malt and vanilla. Some vanilla taste, but not a lot, I hope it hasnt faded already as this is about 4 months old. Lots of roast bitterness, a little coffee and a nice sweet finish. Nice beer.

A vanilla bean stout that should be enough said but Ill go on. The vanilla cuts the rough edges off the roasted bitterness making this a quite pleasant brew. easy to enjoy and most definitely easy to over imbibe. So watch yourself.
Aroma of vanilla, roast coffee and cocoa.  Pours thick and black with a huge brown head.  Taste is roasty with coffee and vanilla notes.  Very dark and tasty.  I love it.

Really like this one.  Approaching pitch black in appearance.  Aroma of roasty goodness and chocolate.  Flavor is much like the aroma.  Lots of dark roasty malt and chocolate coming through.  Finishes dry.  Very nice.
Pours a near black.  Aroma is dark chocolatey malt.  Taste is smokey, chalky and dark with a mild sweetness and small bitter bite in the finish

Big Bottle.  Poured a big, fluffy head.  Nice aroma of vanilla flavored beans, cocoa, and coffee.  Medium light sweetness, light bitter.  Creamy texture.  Taste is identical to flavor.  Slight bitter coffee flavor aftertaste.  Pretty good overall.

Bottle Pours dark brown with a small, fizzy, khaki head. The nose offers lots of fudge and dark chocolate interwoven with more delicate notes of roasted nuts and vanilla. Light to medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation. The flavor and finish are sweet, chocolaty and nutty with a dash of  vanilla at the wee end. Bottle courtesy of atxdelivery!

Location/Date:Bottle split with Ben on November 17th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours dark brown opaque with white head. 
Aroma: Aroma of faint roast, vanilla bean.. 
Taste: Roast, faint vanilla.   
Palate: Medium body.
Summary:

Bottle; Pour is murky brown with a modest khaki brown head in this glass - this beer has a nice cocoa, roast, vanilla nose - the flavor profile has a roast bitterness initial, some fairly nice sweetness through the center, with the vanilla poking through here - the finish is more roast and some sweetness - overall,  a very nice stout attempt here

Location: 500 ml bottle from Norms, 11/17/12


Aroma: The nose is chocolate, vanilla, some roasted malts, and a little bit of coffee

Appearance: This one pours a dark brown-black color with a small beige head

Flavor: The taste is a little sweet, heavy malty, pretty toasty, and with a mild bitterness

Palate: The body is medium-plus, it feels creamy, has a soft carbonation, and a lengthy, lightly dry finish

Overall Impression: 
I thought this was a really solid beer, but it didnt approach world class for me.  Still though, it was very solid, and the flavors were right in-line with what they were going for.  The vanilla doesnt overpower, instead, it adds a nice component.  Good stuff.

Bottle. Nice fluffy khaki head, on a mahogany murky body that closes on black. Lots of cocoa nibs, slight roast, and slighty dry sweet aroma. Chocate dominates the flavor but in a subdued and nice way, slight toast, drier finish. Lighter to medium very fluffy and sod body is where this wins

Solid offering!  Pours black with a creamy tan head that fades quickly.  Big vanilla and chocolate aromas.  Medium bodied and smooth, lactose in mouth.  Sticky finish with bitter chocolate notes and a hint of vanilla.

Bottle. Nice dark black pour with thin head. Aroma is roasty, some vanilla, toasted grain, some chocolate as well. Taste is good, lots of vanilla flavor without being sweet, crisp, grainy, and roasty. Palate is med-light bodied with med carb. Very drinkable.

500ml bottle purchased at Spirits Brick. Poured a pitch black body with an ample beige foamy head. Aroma of chocolate pudding skins, roastiness, burnt toast, vanilla beans. Medium bodied with some decent roastiness and average to sfoter carbonation but a bit of a slight pick up on the back end of the swallow that feels almost acidic. Flavor is coffee grounds, black coffee and cream, vanilla beans. Solid beer.

Dark brown pour with beige head, decent lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, vanilla bean, and mild roast.  Light, creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor is milk chocolate, very light vanilla, which I appreciate, and a dry roasty finish.  Overall a luscious, mild porter.  Very drinkable, but also rich and tasty.

New Beer Distributors, NY 50l ($7.50): Pours black with a brown head. Chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and roasted malts. Taste is like a vanilla, chocolate, coffee smoothie. Very smooth, very creamy. No booziness. Well-balanced. Maine Beer is good.
Almost black, thin tan head.  Very roasty, boozy, and thin.  Coffee flavor and vanilla in the finish.  Really thin, not my favorite.

Bottled 10/7/12 super fresh 3 week old! Pour has a super dark brown color and a nice thick one finger brown head. Aroma has chocolate, nice malts, vanilla, and light roast. Mouth feel is nice and rich, somewhat creamy, and has medium carbonation. Flavor has roasted malt, oats, faint vanilla oil, cocoa, and light coffee bitterness. Really well balanced and like a beer milkshake. Yum!

Pours a pitch black color with a medium brown head. Interesting aroma of roasted malt and vanilla. Good flavor of roasted malt and vanilla with mild sweetness and a bitter finish. Medium body with a slightly creamy texture and medium carbonation.

500ml bottle:  This one pours an opaque, inky dark brown.  There was a small tan head on it that doesnt leave much lacing.  Nice nose.  Chocolate, some roastiness, vanilla, coffee.  Nice taste.  Medium bodied, but still has a lighter feel even though there is a lot of flavor.  Milk chocolate, hint of coffee, faint vanilla.  Balanced well to have almost no sweetness and a hint of bitterness in the finish.  Nice!
Pours dark brown with a 1-fingered tan head.  Smells of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, floral.  Taste is bitter and mildly sweet, dark chocolate, vanilla, rich roast malt flavor, mild hops presence.

pours almost black with a decent medium dark beige head, some retention and lacing. complex roasted profile, bitter coffee and chocolate. some resin, yeast, vanilla. hint of sweetness and lactiness. soft carbonation, full body, nice medium long resinous yet citrusy finish. nice.
From a bottle poured a dark brown/black color with a good amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor with a light toasty finish.

Bottled October 7, 2012.

A: The body is an excellent pitch black with only a thin dark tan head, the head has poor retention but has a light coating and ring on the top.

S: The aroma is strong of coffee and cocoa with very light vanilla in the background. The aroma is very smooth and balanced.

T: The main flavor is a bitter coffee flavor with light cocoa and light vanilla, the vanilla is most prominent on the finish while the cocoa is in the middle.

M: Medium bodied with medium carbonation, mildly fizzy.

O: Very good stout, especially for the ABV. The vanilla and cocoa are really subdued which is a good and a bad thing, overall this is a solid beer though, just a tad expensive.

500ml bottle from City Market Burlington.
Appearance : Pitch black with small foamy brown head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma :  Rich and silky roasted malt with with light coffee and some chocolate. Light vanilla notes. Light woody notes, light resinous notes. 

Taste : Rich roasted malt with coffee and chocolate. Coffee is more present on the arrival while chocolate comes more powerful on the finish. Late finish bring back the coffee with resinous hops. Light coffee acidity all along.

Palate : Soft carbonation. Nice rich silky body. Great carbonation for the style.

Overall : Wow another great beer. Nice big malty presence. Rich but sharp with well defined flavors. Great balance between malt and hops. Awesome texture. Utterly drinkable. Acidity is a tiny bit over the level that I enjoy. Outstanding as always with Maine Beer Company.

Heres another quality beer from this brewery.  Dark pour with a thick creamy tan head that eventually completely fades away.  Chocolate, ash, oats, a little bit of vanilla, as well as a touch of oak in the aroma.  Nice.  The flavors are also good, but not quite as impressive as the scent.  Its very smooth going down.  I wouldnt call it thin but its easier going than expected.  Mocha combines with caramel, wood, and vanilla to comprise of the flavors.  The vanilla really doesnt stand out and its fair to wonder whether I would have noticed it if I wasnt looking for it.  The finish is nice and dry with some bitter pine hops.  Very solid stuff.

Poured from a bottle received from Lukaduke. Thanks! Poured into a tulip glass. Pours a nice dark brown with a tan-ish head of foam that remains to the last sip. The aroma has nice notes of vanilla beans on top of a chocolaty, malty base. The vanilla beans contribute a nice sweetness to the taste on top of the already semi-sweet stout. Very good beer.

Pours black with a big khaki head. Aroma is roasted malts and cocoa. Taste is the same but with a surprising alcohol note for such a low ABV beer. Vanilla is nowhere to be found. Great silly mouthfeel. Might do better aged. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

In short: A velvety semi-roasted stout with vanilla notes.  Decent beer.
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed relatively fresh, 3 months after bottling date (I LOVE breweries that print exact bottling dates on the label)
The look: Black body topped by a medium dark beige head
In long: Nose is medium roasted, notes of old black coffee and only light notes of vanilla.  Taste is very creamy and velvety, light coffee notes, some vanilla extract, milky sensation, good presence of herbaceous hops in the finish.  This beer actually tastes like a moderately roasted oatmeal stout with some vanilla extract added.  I expected more vanilla (not a complain) because of the label description but the vanilla beans are far from overwhelming.  All in all Im almost disappointed by this beer, every other output from this fine brewery really stood out from the crowd, however this Mean Old Tom stout is very good but nothing special.  Far from their best beer effort, this is still a solid beer by this environmentally conscious brewery, proud member of the 1% For The Planet movement, but never mind the environment, just think about how much the next generation will hate us when they realize weve taken all the good usernames!!!

On tap at Pizza Paradiso (Wash. DC).  Pours a dark brown color with hints of red on the edges and  a small off white head that falls quicly to a cap.  Aroma of  roasted black malt, some chocolate, and hints of vanilla. Taste is vanilla, creamy dark malts, chocolate, hint of roast, caramel, and some light earthy hops.  Lightly roasted and dry finish.  Mouthfeel is relatively thin with decent carbonation.

Bottle at craft ale house. Pours black with limited sticky head on top. The aroma is full of vanilla, roast, cocoa, and a little lactose. Taste is very roast with a little vanilla and a coffee bitterness. I really like this.
I enjoyed this brew. I had high expectations for this beer and it happily met them. Very good company and I love the packaging.

500mL bottle, pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma of oatmeal, light roasted malt, and some powdered cocoa. Flavour brings out some moderately roasted malt upfront, with some powdered cocoa and much subtler vanilla in back. Finishes thick, like an oatmeal stout with a nice velvety body. A hearty, easy-drinking stout here. Very solid.

500ml bottle picked up at the source... Pours a porter-lime almost black hue, less intense at the edges, and topped with a creamy light beige head that reduces down to a wispy film... Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and grain backing... Flavors are more of the same with Additional hints of brown sugar and a very lightly bitter roast finish. Smooth creamy body with semi-prickly carbonation. Vanilla peaks through here and there but isnt overly assertive although asserts itself more after warming. Pretty solid.

bottle: delicious, gorgeous beer. Dark, black pour. Nose is chocolate, hint of grains. Smooth bodied but not that heavy. Rich chocolate, toasted, roasty grains. Warm vanilla, brown sugar and molasses and a touch of smoke.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2014 Pours a thick black with a brown head. Smells really good, with vanilla and coffee. Taste is a little more subtle the the smell. Coffee flavors, with a slight vanilla aftertaste. Good. Had in the bottle in Vermont. On tap, beer is even creamier with lots of natural vanilla. Had on tap at Finback Alehouse in Bar Harbor.

how do they do this. How does Maine Beer Company keep topping expectations. Dark black body with fluffy tan head. Aroma is a sweet mix of vanilla and coco, like a chocolate vanilla swirl cone with just a bit of leather chair and coffee beans added. Taste is so well balanced sweetness with some roast and earthiness. Bit more vanilla on the finish. Aud just lightest carbonation to keep the palate alive. Love this beer.

Picked this up for about $5 at the local beer store. Enjoyed in a white wine glass. Pours a dark black, nice solid 2 finger tan head that fades slowly with nice lacing. Scent is very malty with hints of coffee. Taste is more of the same. Roasted malts, vanilla, coffee and some very light milk chocolate. Interesting and very low ABV for a stout.

Bottle. Black beer with a great lasting brownish head. Coffee aroma, malty, cocoa powder, dark chocolate, figs, roasted, peat notes, hay, figs, licorice, viol, tar notes. Coffee and vanilla flavor, woody, salty, peppery, milk, tar, peat, figs, raisins, licorice, chilli notes, hay, dark chocolate, cocoa powder. Lovely balance, long bitter peat finish, hay, roasted, dark chocolate, salt and licorice. Just lovely!

[bottle]
Slight prune and toast behind vanilla roast and vanilla beans. Opaque black under an eternal, tan, lacy cover. Complex flavour that is not lacking in vanilla, but complemented with vanilla roast, plum and other dried fruit and a good sweet/bitter balance, if a bit on the sweet side. Medium body, moderate carbonation, faint bitter chocolate finish.

1 pt 9 oz bottle from bottle shop in Philly. This is my 3rd type of beer from   Maine Brewing Company and I have not been disappointed by them yet. Upon popping the cap, extremely fragrant chocolate coffee smell.  Pours a nice dark syrup.  Not sure if I can taste the vanilla beans much, but probably better that way,  A really nice creamy milkshake consistency with a delicious  smooth  roasted coffee flavor.  Very delicious.  Highly recommended.

Bottle. Heavy malt notes of toasted, coffee and milk chocolate, moderate resin and earth for the hops andyeast with faint wood and charcoal in the background. Head is large, creamy, beige with darker swirls, with good yet slippery lacing and is fully lasting. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts slightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderateyl bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy with a soft carbonation and a chalky finish. This is a bolder than the Stouts Ive had, perhaps its part of the reason I think its one of the best.
Bottle. Black with tan head. Nose/taste of dry roast chocolate malt, burnt toast, roast black coffee and vanilla bean. Dry dark roast finish. Medium body.

50cl bottle pours an opaque black with some creamy beige head.  Inviting aroma, malty, molasses, vanilla, cola, light milk chocolate.  Flavor is sweet, cola, vanilla, molasses, crackers, bread, chocolate.  Medium bodied, sweet, vanilla finish.

500ml bottle from Capones, Norristown. Im a sucker for a stout like this when its well rendered, and this one certainly fit the bill. Base beer was a sumptuous, rich dry stout with all the merits I look for in the style: chocolate malts, dry toasty flavors, nice chalky mouthfeel. But what makes Tom a success is the very *subtle* integration of the additional flavors, nothing artificial or excessive about them. Would love to try this one on draft.

Pour a deep black with a big three finger frothy mocha head that sticks like a champ to the sides of my tulip glass.... Aromas are everything i hoped rich chocolate, vanilla bean, roasted malts and just a hint of birthday cake sweetness.  On the palate its smooth creamy and delicious... like the moist piece of heavenly chocolate cake that was dusted with bittersweet cocoa to add just a hint of bitter quench on the tasty finish. Great stout that doesnt KO you with a huge abv... well done once again Maine Beer Co !
Sampled at the 2012 Lansdale Beer Fest. A lovely beer though it is hard to remember its subtleties from that overwhelming festival.

More of a dessert stout. It has the beautiful black pour as expected. The aroma has a ton of chocolate and vanilla along with a hint of roast coffee. The flavor is very similar with the chocolate and vanilla shining though. It is nicely balanced and goes well with chocolate cake or a scoop of vanilla ice cream. I was tempted to ask my server for a vanilla ice cream float, maybe next time.
Bottle pours opaque black with thick tan head. Vanilla, roast, nuts. Moderately bitter and sweet. Smooth, medium bodied. Looses some of its initial appeal by the time you hit the bottom of the glass.

Thanks to Reynolds314 for this one in trade.  Cheers, Matt!  Pours a stout brown with a tan head.  Nose is earth, cocoa, and slight vanilla with bits of roast.  Flavor is similar with roasted malts, earth, cocoa, and slight vanilla with some chocolate.  Light to medium in body. Mostly balanced and an interesting stout, but not what I imagined it to be.

Pours dark brown, paperthin head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and chocolate, muted. Taste follows. Not anything too special

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From tap at Churchkey. Pours dark brown to black with a small chocolate brown head. Aroma is roasted dark malty and chocolate. Smooth toasted malty, vanilla and slight caramelish. Lingering dark malty and light vanilla into the finish.

Draft at Churchkey. Luscious black pour with a creamy tan head. Nose holds amazing vanilla and chocolate notes, with touches of roasted malt and lactic sugar. Flavor holds more superbly complex sweetness with chocolate truffle, vanilla, almond and marzipan, caramel, and good touches of cacao nibs and roasted malt to add bitterness to the finish. This brewery has just killed it so far.

Bottle courtesy of Andy, split with him and James. Black pour, medium-sized coffee-colored head, not a lot of lacing, some spots. Coffee aroma, notes of light chocolate. Creamy palate with notes of coffee and vanilla cream/icing. Coffee is the main flavor but still not dominant or overpowering. A little nuttiness, almost like a brown-stout-porter mix.
Tap at Stagshead on my solo drinking adventure.  Pours jet black with nice frothy head.  Tastes of vanilla, cocoa, toasted malt, resin, and slight floral.  Light and easy drinking stout but pleasant

Bottle poured a deep dark brown with a medium tan head that dissapated quickly and minimal lacing.  Aroma is huge roasted bold coffee with hints of vanilla and caramel malt.  Taste is well-balanced blend of smokey roasted coffee, a touch of vanilla, and palatable bitterness of espresso.  Nice creamy mouthfeel with smooth finish.  Very enjoyable, drinkable stout.

Pours a three finger light brown head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Black color no highlights, ton of yeast left in bottle. Good carbonation and light-medium bodied.  Vanilla nose and flavor is sweet vanilla and roasted coffee. Decent stout. $6.49 for a 500ml bottle from Beverage Warehouse Winooski, VT.

Basic stout. Almost no vanilla flavor. I would not have this again. Rather boring example of the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The aroma is roasty, chocolate, vanilla.  The appearance is deep brown, opaque, light tan head.  The flavor is roast, dark, bitter chocolate, vanilla.  Medium in body, maybe slightly thicker than medium, light for a stout.  The finish is roasty, bitter chocolate, pine.  The vanilla doesnt jump right to the front here.  Still, an enjoyable stout.

From a very fresh 0.5l bottle into a brandy snifter. Pours a very dark black, not even brown but just black. Not much lacing and a tiny bit of brown foam on top. Aroma is light and reminiscent of a very sweetened latte. Mouthfeel is fantastic. Medium but feels lighter than it should. It's also smooth and dry but slightly oily at the same time?!?!?!?!?!  Taste is mainly coffee, chalk, ash, lemon, and oak. Overall an excellent beer. Glad I tried it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Coffee aroma with flavors of coffee, chocolate and vanilla. The palate is a bit thin but its a tasty stout overall.

On tap in dc  Decent brew. Perhaps served a little too cool. Mostly cocoa and roastiness on nose and taste. Not much vanilla happening here.  Good mouthfeel made this a relatively easy drinking  and enjoyable brew but overall a tad disappointed in overall flavour/complexity. Aphrodite by ddc a similar brew  but superior in my books

A - Pours a dark black-brown with a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted chocolate malts with vanilla, cocoa, and coffee.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted dark and chocolate with some sweet vanilla and cocoa. Through the middle, some coffee comes through alongside some more roasted and lightly burnt flavors. The finish is a mix of roasted chocolate and coffee with some vanilla.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, roasted, and lightly sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nicely balanced American Stout. The vanilla adds a nice complexity to the beer.

Roasted malt, vanilla, and some coffee/chocolate in the aroma.  Flavor starts sweet and malty, with the vanilla a lot more subtle than youd think.  Finish has coffee/cocoa bitterness.  This is the first beer Ive tried from this company, and Ill look for more.
Draft.  Deep4⃣black color. Slightly hoppy. vanilla sweet taste of. Milk malt and cream. Good stout

Bottle.  Black with small tan head, web like lace.  Nose of cocoa, roast, light vanilla and earthy notes.  Flavor is fairly straight forward, roast and cocoa, some herbal, earthy bitterness, not too much vanilla.  A little slick on the mouf.  Purty good.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2015 Bottle pour into pint glass. Thin dirty cream colored head rapidly dissipates. Opaque dark coffee color. Slightly sweet molasses mixed with roasted malt and chocolate in the nose. Medium body in the mouth. Chocolate and roast notes continue. Early bitter touch gives way to prominent roast in the finish and a earthy, dirt note as well. Not really getting the vanilla anywhere. Respectable easy drinking stout but not remarkable.

Bottle, 05/23/2012.  Pours deep brown, creamy beige tan head with solid retention.  Nice aroma with soft coffee roast, milk chocolate powder, nice vanilla highlight.  Taste a little heavier roast, subtle chocolate, dark chocolate vanilla, but perhaps a bit rougher than the aroma.  Medium thin palate, easy drinking and smooth.  Elegant stout.
Bottle:  Pours a dark ruby with a medium tan head, aroma has vanilla bean and chocolate, starts and ends bitter with a vanilla aftertaste, medium bodied with ample carbonation, slick mouthfeel.

Bottle, pours midnight black, small off white head, tons of lacing. Aromas of strong vanilla bean, roast, chocolate. Taste is smooth with vanilla, espresso, cocoa, sweet malt, wood, and a touch of hop flavor hidden in the back. Excellent natural tasting stout.

Aroma chocolate, vanilla, coffee, Pours black with thick tan head that dissipates to constant ring with lacing. Taste chocolate, coffee and vanilla sneaks through, slightly roast. medium body slightly dry on the palate with pleasant chocolate coffee finish. Very good stout!

Thanks to the folks at Boston Wine Exchange.  Bottled on 5/3 - drank it on 5/15.  Love it.  Perfect black pour with a khaki-colored head that lingered for the appropriate amount of time.  Nice roasty aroma, but the vanilla was not present (very faint).  Was hoping for a little bit more strength in the vanilla on the nose and palate.  Its a delicate balancing act (too strong and it gets perfumey!).  Wonderful roasted coffee flavor on the palate - would be an exceptional pairing with rich chocolate desserts.  A very good stout - would recommend and will buy again.
On draft at Isaac Newtons.  This here Old Tom is a light session stout, with some nice esters that come into the picture.  Really good.

Bottle from Julios. Pours jet black into the glass with a big frothy tan head. Vanilla-malty aromas. Flavor is very, very smooth. Cocoa-vanilla notes with lots of toffee-caramel on the finish. Low hopped, but well balanced and not too sweet. Lingering earthy-grass notes too. This one gets better as it warms.

On tap at The Great Lost Bear in Portland, ME. Pours a black body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is slightly sweet roasts and dark chocolates with a moderate vanilla, some milk chocolates, and a touch of coffee. Flavor is similar. Dark and milky chocolates up front with a moderately sweet roast and a touch of lactose sweetness as well. A lighter, but smooth vanilla comes out nicely towards the end and blends well with the big chocolates and roasts. A touch of coffee and char comes out as the roastiness grows into the finish and this dries with a roasty, medium-light bitterness and very smooth chocolate malt backing. A light vanilla lingers with the roasts and rich chocolates in a lengthy aftertaste. Overall, a solid stout. Plenty of rich, milky and dark chocolates with a nice roast backing giving off some pleasant coffee notes. Smooth and easy drinking making this an enjoyable beer.
Draft. Almost black, small beige edge head. Aroma of cocoa powder and milk chocolate. Taste is mocha, coffee, chocolate. Tasty.

500 ml bottle shared by emmasdad ( thans Dan) pooured a translucent dark brown nearly black with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of milk chocolate, carmel and vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of milk chocolate, vanilla and light carmel with a smooth lingering vanilla finish.

Super dark brown with minimal head. Very earthen nose- almost manure like with vanilla and toffee back notes. Cocoa nib, milk chocolate, vanilla bean, and creamy latte in flavor. Medium body for the style with a sweet chocolate finish.

A deep dark stout with a thin compact lacing off white head. In aroma, a smooth coffee chocolate with herbal notes, and light creaminess. In mouth, a smooth bitter chocolate with grassy metallic hops, burned wood, nice and smooth. On tap at Reservoir, Waterbury, April 6 2012.

Des notes de torréfaction séchappe du verre et surmonte un liquide noir au collet crème presque blanc. La bouche est vraiment surprenante, juste au moment où lon croit que le chocolat va simposer, un filet de vanille apparait. Le mélange café vanille se poursuit dans larrière-goût de façon magistrale. Buvabilité évidente malgré le bagage de saveurs assez étoffé. Belle trouvaille.
This was almost a perfect stout. Complex toasty roasty notes over the soft vanilla. Just really a wonderful beer that I was happy to share the experience with a friend.

Draft. Pours black with a tan head. Sweet vanilla and chocolate aroma with light roasted malts. The flavor has sweet vanilla, lightly roasted malts, chocolate, and is well balanced with flowery hops. A touch on the thin side, but still really good.
On tap at Blind Tiger. Pours black with creamy beige head. Slightly roasty aroma; some nice coffee notes. Flavor is mild of caramel and cocoa. Weak, watery mouthfeel. Not nearly enough malt here.

Pours dark brown, almost black, in color with a small off-white head.  Roast is the dominant aroma here with a fair amount of chocolate and cocoa.  Smells a bit...dusty?  Some hints of vanilla, but not as much as I would have expected.  The flavor is a touch watery and thin.  Does have a nice chocolate and vanilla character, though.  Good, but could have been better.
nice solid vanilla stout here. nothing too insane, but very solid, very tasty, nothing wrong with it. a ba version would be really killer.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2016 Bottle, thanks to Leighton. It pours very dark brown, with a thin tan head. The nose is caramel, vanilla, roasted malt and cocoa powder. The taste is roasted malt, charcoal, smoke, hay, dryness, coffee and some milk chocolate, with a dry finish. Light-medium body and low-moderate carbonation. It would be nice to have a touch more sweetness to balance it out. Decent and easy drinking stuff though.
Nose is roast, sweet milky malt, dark honey, cocoa.  Flavor is cocoa, roast, milk chocolate, some dark fruit.  Vanilla comes out in the super dry finish w. a bit of burnt character.

Draft at blind tiger. Pours deep black body with no head, light carbonated lacing. Aroma is smoky and sweet roast and toasted notes. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of smoked malts, sweet roast, toasted bread, and a solid hop presence. Good beer.
bottle from Rudolf. dark black pour, big roasty aroma with chocolate & light coffee notes. Didnt gather much vanilla. Good roasty flavor, very drinkable & enjoyable.

Wow, who knew such good things could come from Maine?  Dark pour with thick tan head and good lacing.  Sweet chocolate aroma.  A nice mix of milk chocolate and roast.  Smooth and silky.  Not mean at all.

Good medium bodied stout. This beer catches a lot of the "Its not very impressive" slag from the scene in my experience, I tell people that stout doesnt have to be 12%abv and aged in Pappy Van Winkle barrels to be good. This is a prime example.  Nice roast on the nose followed by creamy vanilla and a chocolate-earthiness underneath.  flavors are the same.  Very nice medium-dry finish.  Good body for a medium stout.

Pint bottle, poured a more thicker than thin coca-cola dark brown color, with aroma of creamy chocolate, vanilla, roast, and some sweet malt.  Flavors are much the same, balanced the aromas nicely.  Real enjoyable beer that I could drink over and over again.

Bottle.  Fully opaque black with creamy full lasting head and decent lace.  Full roast and chocolate malts aromas and flavors. Some lactic sourness with hints of the vanilla which i am glad is not strongly expressed.  The balance bitter and sweet is good.  Pretty creamy and thick mouthfeel.  It is a very pleasant and easy drinking stout.  it is not as much of a standout as their others but i am glad they went for an every day kind of stout rather than something super big and bold...though i would buy that on sight if they did.

Part of a trade thanks to TWStandley, cheers!

Pours black with about a finger of light tan head. Smell is a pretty solid amount of roasty espresso. Taste is a lot lighter than some stouts. Vanilla is certainly there, but it sort of comes out as a bit of a heavier regular stout. Very drinkable and not too heavy. Good beer.

Bottle shared by B3C. Poured a black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt and chocolate aroma. Medium to heavy chocolate sweet flavor with a medium to heavy vanilla sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This is a good beer.

Bottle at home in London with Paul. Pours brown with a small, beige foam head. Burnt cocoa, roasty malt aroma. Medium sweet flavor, light vanilla notes, cocoa, light burnt earth bitterness. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Some dusty cocoa to finish, some lightly roasted malts, light toasted grass, subtle burnt sugar. Some sweet tobacco. A really nice, easily drinkable stout. I like it.
