My first beer from Maine Beer Co! Dark opaque black color, steady creamy beige head. Roasted, coffeish aroma. Medium-bodied. Toasted, soft, vanilla, coffeish with hints of tobacco. Classic robust stout. Great brew!

500mL from Beer Heaven in Philly. Clear, deep marron looking black in the snifter. Thick, dense, beige head. Exceptional creamy appearance. Moderate lacing. Nose is nicely subtle: tiramisu, rum soaked lady fingers, sharp cocoa, lemony twang, acidic coffee. Taste is thinner than expected and a bit dirty to earthy with mild grittiness. Not quite what I was expecting given the ridiculous reputation of this new brewery: MO, Zoe, Lunch, Spring Peeper. Needs a little work. Still, nicely refreshing and on the lighter side of stout.

I get coffee on the nose, dark malts and perhaps a touch of vanilla. 
Sweet Roasty taste with coffee on the finish, smooth mouth feel , not bad , their Peeper ale remains one of the standout beers.

500ml bottle in an English pint.  Pours black with a thick, lacy, beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla, a little chocolate, and some floral, almost citrusy hops.  Flavor about the same, and the vanilla blends in well and doesnt overpower the stout.  Average texture.  A pretty good beer.

Bottle shared by Peter at STL RB gathering, thanks!.  Pour is dark brown with a thin tan head.  Flavor is lightly sweet roasted malt with light hints of vanilla and faint brown sugar. Maybe a touch of nuttiness and chocolate in there as well. Nothing too crazy but solid for sure.
Brewed 01/09/12. Black body with no head whatsoever. Smells a little of chocolate and vanilla. Lit bit of vanilla on the back end but not much.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark brown body, creamy khaki head, decent lacing.

S: Chocolate, roasted malts including mild coffee notes, hints of vanilla and caramel.

T: A bit muddled as the chocolate and roasted malts kind of step on each other as they fight to assert their presence.

M: Medium full bodied, lacking the creamy smoothness of good chocolate stouts at this moderate ABV level.  Hints of bitterness in the finish.

O: An unassuming stout that does little to stand out in a field where boldness or balance typify the greats.
Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Pours black with a tan head.  Flavor is predominantly coffee with a little dark chocolate.  Medium bodied.  Overall a pretty solid stout.
cocoa and sweetness with a lightish body for a stout. creamy vanilla taste alongside a light malt and hop character with bitter finish. some burnt coffee husk and bread and small grittiness.
Bottle shared by Madvike, thanks Matt.  Good roast on the nose, but the flavor is lacking of said roast.  OK, but I had expected a bit more from the nose.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours black with just a bit of light showing through and a thin foamy tan head. Nice roast on the nose, with vanilla sweetness and a touch of heat. The initial whiff was nice, but it became a little less pungent as it sat in the glass. Smooth taste. A bit milky with a big roast component, some vanilla and a bit of charcoal. A bit thin. Unoffensive, but theres nothing about it that would make me want to drink it again.

500 ml bottle from lushawn- thanks a lot, Shawn! Pours a dark brown color with amber highlights and a medium tan head. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, brown sugar, molasses, and some coffee-like roasted malts. Very nice-smelling without being messy at all as a lot of vanilla stouts are. Flavor of dark chocolate, rich and roasty coffee, vanilla, toasted brown sugar, and molasses. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, roasty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Excellent.

Tasted from tall bottle at 2nd STL Ratebeer Gathering. Poured a very dark brown color with thick, tan, persistent head with lace. Aromas of roasted barley, malt, coffee, dark chocolate, real vanilla. Starts with typical dry stout flavors: mellow malt, roasted grains, burnt toast, tangy hops bitterness, chalk, but with LOTS more coffee and vanilla essence. Medium body, low carbonation, fruity and toasty aftertaste. This is a well-crafted stout in a strength you could still drink in quantity. Highly recommended.

Pure blackness resides under the lasting beige sheet. As with other Maine Beer Co products, this stout is done with elegance. Its vanilla and cocoa components never feel exagerated, certainly without the slightest hint of artificiality. Roasted malts with a dose of resfreshing and never clashing acidity punctuate the aroma. Clean and powdery, almost chalky cocoa finish dries out the sweetish vanilla middle. Medium bitterness climbs up, seeming to come more from the roast than the soft earthy hops. Remaning easy to drink through and through despite the relative thickness. The rather active, albeit small-bubbled carbonationseems to help drinkability, contributing to cutting through the chocolatey sweetness. A good stout, but without the lively and fresh character I dig so much in their pale ales.
On draft.  Pitch black with a light tan head.  Chocolate, and hints of vanilla.  A nice drinking stout.  Just a hair thin.

Bottle pours deep opaque brown with a khaki colored head. The aromas as I pour it is simply amazing with lots of sweet vanilla, some roastiness, and a bit of toffee. Taste is amazingly balanced ad smooth with cocoa, roasted malt, and vanilla, not too bitter or sweet.  Overall, a great stout.

500ml bottle, dated 11/10/2011 and aged about 3 months.  The pour yields a dark, slightly translucent cola-mahogany body.  A thick cap of khaki colored froth sits at the head, showing excellent retention and leaving a dense, tattered swath of cobweb lacing behind.  Aromas are based in nicely toasted barley malt, hinting at coffee and toasted bread, and loaded with dry roasted cacao beans.  Vanilla sits on the periphery, staying out of the way from the roast cocoa scents.  The flavor largely follows suit, showcasing chocolate and coffee roast prominently, bitterness trumping the subtle, toasty caramel sweetness underneath.  I really dont get much vanilla at all, but thats not necessary a bad thing.  The mid-note is long and biting, with a decidedly oaty-cocoa finish.  In the mouth, the moderate body sports a smooth, very slightly milky-chalky consistency, with a nice, soft carbonation.  Theres a hint of acidity as well, reminiscent of aging coffee.  Overall, its quite a solid brew, but it certainly isnt life changing.
bottle from ernesto thanks! pours black with fast fading head. aroma of coffee and roasted nuts. taste is medium chewy oatmeal vanilly goodness

pours an almost completely black color with a lovely sized tan head. dark chocolate malts and roasted malts are prominent in the nose. smells great! extremely smooth to drink. carbonation is there but its just enough in my opinion. dark cocoa nibs and slight vanilla come through in the taste. just a relatively simple and wonderfully done beer. wow... a real treat my friends cheers!

Nice vanilla note. Possible hint of caramel. Light mouthfeel. Excellent
Also from the greatest state in the nation.
Pours a dark brown with a fluffy light brown lacing. Heavy notes of chocolate and coffee, with a vanilla also noticeable

Bottle courtesy of McGrupp612. Served in a mug.

Pours a deep near-black color with a very nice tan head and some good lacing on the way down. The nose brings forward quite a bit of chocolate and vanilla along with a touch of roast. Flavor goes quite a bit down from there with far too much roast. Simply an average stout profile. Medium body with good carbonation and a slight vanilla finish. Decent enough, but not something Id go back to really.

Pours dark brown/black with a thick and creamy tan head...wonderful lacing and retention.  Aroma has nice cocoa notes...a bit of sweetness...and just a hint of vanilla.  Flavor is nice and roasty with cocoa and vanill coming together nicely.  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with a mildly roasty cocoa finish.  Not super complex but expertly crafted and very tasty!

Bottle.  Pours a deep black with a thin tan head.  Chocolate and roast, a touch of vanilla.  Chocolate, vanilla, roast and cocoa.  Smooth, medium bodied, nice and roasty.  Cocoa, long roast and bitterness on the finish.  Long bitterness on the finish.  Very nice.

16 oz. Bottle. $5.99 @ Carls Meat Market, Kittery ME. Deep brown with reddish tints. Thick tan head that dies to a thin layer. Some retention with spotty lace. Nose is exclusively rich, chocolate malt. The flavor is where this one really shines. Roasted grain, chocolate malt, coffee and a nice, natural vanilla toward the back of the sip. Not overly sweet or overdone. Body is Medium to full with a nice creamy texture. Lightly dry finish. Really nice. Once I finished I wanted more.

16oz bottle.  Pours a nice brown/black hue, decent head.  Aromas are very subdued, but a sharper cocoa and light vanilla are present.  Palate is decent, sweet malts hit up front then a lighter cocoa and vanilla through the mid.  Finish is a tad bland and short, but decent.  The vanilla is ok, not overwhelming, but simple.

Aroma- cocoa, vanilla, oak
Appearance- flat, mostly black with brown hues, crescent white head
Taste- big vanilla, bitter dark chocolate
Palate- thin for a stout, decent carbonation
Overall- Taste was decent but it was not memorable at all.  Slightly overpriced and forgettable.

On tap at the Publick House. Pours deep black. Aromas are chocolate bitterness, roasted malts, sweet vanilla. The taste is a fine balance between the tart chocolate and the sweet vanilla flavors with some roastiness throughout. Another great offering from the Maine Beer Co. A solid stout.

Bottle poured into a nonic pint.

A - Pours jet black with a one finger tall off white head leaving small wisps of lace down the glass.

S - Smells of coffee, vanilla, chocolate, dark roasted grain, and some light smoke. Nothing amazing but still solid.

T - Starts off with some vanilla sweetness slowly giving way to hints of day old coffee grounds, chocolate, dark roasted malt, and some light smokiness. The thin body really brings this one down a notch or two. Finish is a mix of dark roast and light sweetness, lingering long after consumption.

M - Thin body with a ton of dark roasted flavor, moderate carbonation. This one has lots of roast throughout but the thin feel kinda ruins it.

O - This one was ok. It has some good flavores going for it but it lacks the more substantial body needed to be great IMO. I wont turn down another but I wouldnt go running out of my house to get more.
500 ml bottle from Winter 2011 Secret Santa. Big bitter chocolate and vanilla. Not too heavy and not light. Well done. Smooth and very delicious.

Smoky and sweet roasted malt aroma. Pours dark coffeed in color with a small tan head that disappears quickly. The flavors of light bitter roasted and smoky malts with hints of the vanilla. The body is smooth and just a bit creamy.
Dark brown, beige head. Cocoa, roast, light vanilla aroma. Flavor has coffee, chocolate, roasted malt and very light vanilla.

Bottle from Tullys in Wells Maine. Pours dark brown/black with reddish edges and a 1 finger creamy tan head. Aroma is roasted malt with vanilla bean and hints of cocoa. Flavor is a nice blend of the aforementioned items. Palate is a tad lighter than I would have liked, but it is quite palatable. Very nice. Havent had a beer I didnt like from these folks yet.

Bottle via Pins in PA, shared at SL in MD. Pours like a porter... Decent little brown head, black in color....Nose of some vanilla beans, light chocolate notes, roasted malts. Taste is nice.. light chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla beans... well balanced... very enjoyable... Medium body... not stout like, more of a porter in my opinion. Overall.. Simple, clean, well balanced, drinkable.... winner imo....

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of malt, roasting, chocolate, vanilla, and a hint of Earth.  
Poured very dark brown in color with a small, creamy, dense, tan/light brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, roasting, chocolate, hops, light vanilla, and some caramel.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, roast, chocolate, hop, light vanilla finish.

500mL Bottle, purchased...somewhere in Boston? A silken, clean, plain sugar and chocolate stout aroma. This one shies away from the strong roast and robust char and leans towards the buttery, soft chocolate tones. Flavors reveal this as what I would call a real chocolate stout, with lots of tropical bean flavors and nice mineral notes. The vanilla is properly subtle, supporting, and not gimicky or overwhelming, a first for vanilla in beer for me. Minimal warmth, good integration. The dimensions are solid, but something is not jumping out and popping at me. Unlike my other experiences with Maine Beer, this one doesnt immediately say world class to me. Its good, but not great.

A fairly light brown with reddish tints.  Big tan foam, droopy lacing.  Aroma is roasty, not much vanilla.  Taste is much better, chocolate, sweet, some light vanilla.  I do wish there was more real vanilla bean flavor, but overall it is a solid stout.
Shared ~500ml? bottle with friends. Pretty enjoyable - mild vanilla notes, cocoa dominates. Flavor is rich chocolate, a bit reminiscent of dark chocolate hot chocolate.
Pours a deep black with a medium tan lacing head.  Aroma of light vanilla and cocoa. The flavor is a little more pronounced with the vanilla and cocoa.  Nice stout grainbill coming through.

I found this while shopping for my secret Santa target, merry Christmas to me.
Pours a solid black color with a huge fluffy tan head that exudes great retention and lace. Smells of roasted grain, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, a bit of caramel. Smells nice like a stout with vanilla beans, but not to heavy on the vanilla. Taste is just what I expected from the aroma. A solid roasted grain presence with hints of vanilla and caramel. Medium body and level of carbonation, sweet slick mouthfeel. This is a great simple easy drinking stout. If these werent 7 dollars for 500ml and available only once a century I might actually drink it more often.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 Bottle @ home, huge thanks to Arminjewell. Deep brown/black appearance with a nice brown head. Very nice roasty chocolate malty, rich cocoa, vanilla bean, light, caramel, sweet dessert aroma. Big chocolate malty, moderately roasty, vanilla bean, rich cocoa flavor. Excellent dessert beer that actually is almost on the same level as Aphrodite.

Bottle, thanks to Santa for this one!  Pour is dark black with thin off white almost tan head, aroma has notes of chocolate, cocoa powder, vanilla, toffee and caramel, some sweet coffee/mocha notes in there as well.  Dessert-like for sure.  Taste is a mix of caramel, coffee, chocolate and vanilla, nicely bittering with roast, finishing fairly dry.  This is nice, dessert like but still not very sweet and easy to drink.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown color with a small sized off white head. Roast, chocolate, vanilla, some lighter earthiness, and caramel. Vanilla bean. Tad on the thin side.

Black with light tan head, light lacing, light retention... coffee chocolate and some light vanilla dominate a roasty malty aroma... chocolate w light light vanilla dominate the roasty body,,, medium body dry finish...

A bit thing and watery on the pour and mouthfeel but the aroma and taste are really great.  Vanilla beans and cocoa notes are subtle and charming.  Finish is roasted and lightly hopped.  Smooth easy drinking great offering from MBC

Bottle from Craft Ale House.  Pours jet black, turbid,m no light through direct light, with 1-finger well-retained brown head.  Nose is choc and patent malt, vanilla, roasty, hops.  Tastes smooth, almost to the level of N2ization, with patent and choc malts, hops, complexity abounding, and a dense finish.  This beer clocks in at 6.5 % ABV, yet feels like 11%, and is the 2nd beer tonight who has turned the density/ABV dichotomoy on its head.  My cherry popper from MBC, and Il be craving every subsequent beer these guys make.  Bravo, and say hello to fellow Maine guy Stephen King, one of my all time fav writers.
Bottle, a little thin and watery but great subtle vanilla and roasted malt flavor. I really like the vanilla flavors

Pours black with ceamy tan head with great lacing.  Aroma is roasty, coffee and vanilla.  Taste is sweet with faint traces of coffee bitterness.  Light mouthfeel makes this very easy to drink.  Aroma is best part.
Bottle.  Pours a dark black color with an off white foam head.  Aroma of fruit, cocoa, and vanilla.  Sweet cocoa taste with hints of vanilla.   Roasty.   Pretty solid.

Bottle: pours dark black wit a thick tan head, aroma of vanilla, malt, chocolate, taste is malty, chocolate, roasty/coffee, some vanilla, very smooth beer and not too sweet.  One of the more enjoyable stouts Ive had in a while.

500ml bottle from Pinocchios. Pours a jet black color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is bitter, roasty, chocolate, vanilla, with a bittersweet chocolate finish. A very nice stout thats big on flavor at 6.5%.
16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a dark cola color with a medium sized creamy tan head.  Aroma of malt, cocoa and light vanilla.  Taste of dry malts, cocoa and light vanilla.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with tan froth.  Nose is coffee bean, cocoa and earthy vanilla.  Medium body with a tang.  I was a bit surprised at how bold this was considering the finesse of their other brews.  Begins with espresso, zesty grape and molasses.  Mellows out beautifully with cocoa, vanilla and caramel.  Huge on flavor but not heavy.  Refreshing to see a great stout thats not imperialized.

16 oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Jet black with a creamy beige head. Aromas of slight roast, chalky cocoa, and faint vanilla. Cocoa and vanilla arent as prominent in the taste, but Tom is so balanced and slightly reminds me of Cadillac Mountain Stout. Maine is 2 for 2 in my book, cant wait to try Zoe.

bottle that was bottled 7 days ago.      aroma of hazlenuts, coffee, caramel, creme brulee, and vanilla.   more roast in the taste, pleasant bitter bite. i go in paranoid about vanilla additions, as they sometimes come across as flat, overly sweet, artificial tasting additions.  but this worked well.    dry.  tasty.   awesome fresh stout.
Pours black with a small off white head. Aromas of vanilla, cocoa and espresso. Very drinkable stout. Flavors are very nice.

Pours black into an English pint. Conglomerate head with excellent retention recedes leaving scant sheet lacing to pancake surface. Sweet burnt chocolate aromas. Thin with upfront smoky chocolate and a lasting dry, sweet hot chocolate and resin finish.

Pours a dark brown that appears black and completely opaque in the glass with a two finger beige head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Minimal spots of lace left behind. 

Roasted malt aroma with lots of sweet chocolate countered by a strong vanilla presence. Robust with lots of toast, dark chocolate and roasted coffee bean in the nose which keeps the vanilla in check. 

Medium bodied with a nice balance of roasted and sweet flavors. Lots of dark malt flavor with hints of roasted gourmet coffee, burnt toast, oatmeal and dark chocolate followed by a creamy lactic and sweet vanilla presence mid-palate. I was nervous that this would be a vanilla overload but there is enough of the flavor there without overpowering the stout characteristics. It actually serves as a nice balance to what would otherwise be an overly roasted stout. a bit tame and light bodied for my liking but enjoyable and easy to drink.

Deep brown pour almost black beige head light sticky lacing .... aroma of cocoa, vanilla and slightly roasted .... taste is of vanilla, roasted malts, cocoa and caramel malts with a touch of sweet lactose .... mouthfeel is a bit thin but it is just a stout, abv is hidden really well finishes dry and chocolatey ...  this stuff is dangerous havent had one bad brew from these guys yet ... if they imperial this recipe look out

500ml bottle, batch 1, thanks to Ben.

Pours fairly light for a stout, settling in as a dark opaque chestnut with a small off-white head that recedes to a wispy cap.

Aroma is a really nice mixture of roasted black malts, cocoa powder and vanilla beans.  There is also a slightly more sweet milk chocolate character to the owe as it warms.

Taste is more of the same and really excellent for a regular stout.  Its got the backbone of roasted malts with a layer of sweet chocolate and vanilla on top.  Lightly roasted and dry finish.

The mouthfeel is the one drawback for me as its a little on the thin side for a stout with decent carbonation.

Overall, this is an excellent stout - the vanilla adds the right amount of balance and sweetness to the roasted base.  A little more body and this would be a world class American stout.

(500 ml bottle (batch 1) from Bootleggers)  Pours dark brown with ruby-brown highlights. Three or four fingers of tan head. Deep coffee and chocolate aroma with some vanilla hints. Mouthfeel is smooth and satiny - very inviting. Flavor is deep and roasty, coffee and chocolate, heavier on the coffee. Medium bitter. Hint of grassiness in the finish is the only thing that detracts. Very good.

Tap at Novare, cant believe no one else entered this from that night?!  Had a bunch of these gems myself and I must say I cant wait until they do it again!  Aroma is chocolate cake, vanilla and chocolate....smells amazing.  Flavor is a nice smooth stout, a hint of hops, and a wallop of vanilla.  Smooth and delicate mouthfeel.  This stuff needs to be bottled guys, the world needs to see this.
